Module 1 – Part 3 Topics
• Security Monitoring and Logging

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 3.pptx

document:
Security Monitoring
• Continuous collection of data for detecting security events
• Sources: network devices, servers, firewalls, IDS/IPS, endpoints
• Objectives: identify abnormal patterns and correlate activity

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 3.pptx

document:
Logging Fundamentals
• Logs provide detailed records of system and user activity
• Must be accurate, timestamped, and centralized
• Types of logs: system, application, network, audit, and security

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 3.pptx

document:
Centralized Log Management
• Collect logs from multiple sources
• Store in a secure, tamper-proof system
• Use tools like syslog, ELK stack, or Splunk
• Enables correlation and long-term analysis

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 3.pptx

document:
Network Forensics
• Capturing, recording, and analyzing network traffic for evidence
• Used for post-incident analysis and attack reconstruction
• Tools: Wireshark, tcpdump, Zeek (Bro), NetworkMiner

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 3.pptx

document:
Wireshark Overview
• Popular open-source packet analyzer
• Displays captured packets in detail
• Filters traffic for protocols, IPs, and payloads
• Essential for diagnosing network security issues

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 3.pptx

document:
Incident Response Tools
• Antivirus and EDR (Endpoint Detection and Response)
• Log analyzers and forensic suites
• Network scanners (Nmap, Nessus)
• Memory analysis tools (Volatility, Autopsy)

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 3.pptx

document:
SIEM (Security Information and Event Management)
• Combines log management, monitoring, and analytics
• Correlates events from multiple sources
• Supports real-time alerting and dashboards
• Example: Splunk, IBM QRadar, Elastic Security

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 3.pptx

document:
Indicators of Compromise (IoCs)
• Evidence that a system has been breached
• Examples: unusual outbound traffic, failed logins, file hash changes
• Collected via IDS, SIEM, and endpoint logs

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 3.pptx

document:
Case Study: Phishing Attack Detection
• Employee reports suspicious email
• Logs show login attempt from foreign IP
• Network capture confirms credential exfiltration
• Response: block IP, reset credentials, enhance MFA policy

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 3.pptx

document:
Best Practices for Monitoring
• Enable detailed logging for critical systems
• Regularly review logs and alerts
• Automate correlation using SIEM rules
• Retain logs for compliance (HIPAA, PCI-DSS, etc.)

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 3.pptx

document:
Network Hardening Checklist
• Disable unused ports and services
• Patch and update systems regularly
• Enforce strong password and MFA policies
• Implement network segmentation and least privilege

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 3.pptx

document:
Summary
• Monitoring and forensics are essential for security visibility
• Logging and SIEM tools detect early signs of compromise
• Effective incident response minimizes damage
• Continuous improvement through lessons learned
